event.title: Before Stanford A, Newton must have read Ripley's Opera omnia chemici (Kassel 1649) [cf. FHP p.160 ¶.1] ...................................................................
Before Stanford A, Newton must have read Tractatus aliquot chemica (Geismar 1647) [cf. FHP p.160 ¶.1] ...................................................................
Before Stanford A, Newton must have read Musaeum Hermeticum (Frankfurt 1625) [cf. FHP p.160 ¶.1] ...................................................................
Before Stanford A, Newton must have read Harmoniae imperscrutabilis . . Decas [I-II] (Frankfurt 1625) [cf. FHP p.160 ¶.1] ...................................................................
Before Stanford A, Newton must have read Basilius Valentinus Currus triumphalis antimonii (Frankfurt 1625) [cf. FHP p.160 ¶.1]** ...................................................................

data.event: This book appears in Stanford "A" even though Newton read it earlier.

event.title: Before Stanford A, Newton must have read Nicholas Flammel, his exposition of the hierographical figures (London 1624) [cf. FHP p.160 ¶.2]** ...................................................................

data.event: Newton kept trying to find a copy of this through the 1690s.

event.title: Before Stanford A, Newton must have read George Starkey Pyrotechny asserted (London 1645) [cf. FHP p.161 ¶.0]** ...................................................................

data.event: Newton still added this title to DCS [desiderata] as late as the 1680s.

event.title: Newton likely wrote the aspirational 5-page Stanford A (MS M132/2/4), 'De Scriptoribus Chemicis' [early 1670s cf. FHP, maybe before Apr 1669 cf. DTW]** ...................................................................

Newton likely wrote the 7-page Babson 419, 'Of Chemicall Authors and their writings,' which contains ordered information about authors he extracted from Maier (1617) [1670-75 by handwriting cf. FHP]**

data.event:
Babson MS 419. ALCH00093
FHP p.142 ¶.0 n.22

event.title: Newton likely wrote the 1-page St. Andrews 38195(c), 'Authors by nationality' from Maier (1617) [late 1670s cf. FHP]** ...................................................................
Newton likely wrote the 11-page Stanford B (MS M132/2/3) 'De Script. Chem.' [sometime in the late 1680s cf. FHP]**
Newton likely wrote Keynes 13/A, 'Authors listed chronologically' based on Maier (1617) [late 1680s?? cf. FHP. Post 1696 more likely]**

data.event:
Keynes 13, first part of 3.
mid- or late-1680s, FHP p.142 ¶.0 n.25

event.title: The first edition of Principia Mathematica was published on July 5, 1687. ...................................
Newton likely purchased a copy of Catalogue of Chymicall Books (Wm. Cooper, pub) in this timespan [cf. FHP]*
Newton likely wrote Keynes 13/B, 'Authors listed chronologically' [early 1690s cf. FHP]**

data.event:
Keynes 13, second part of 3.
FHP p.142 ¶.0 n.25

event.title: Newton likely compiled the 2-page Babson 418, 'Lib. Chem', part 2, inventory of his library [about 1696-97, cf. FHP]**
Newton must have moved from Cambridge to London in this time span.
Newton likely wrote Keynes 13/C 'Authors listed chronologically' [early 1700s cf. FHP]**

data.event:
Keynes 13, second part of 3.
FHP p.142 ¶.0 n.25

event.title: A book-sellers' list survives from this time bearing the title 'Books for Mr. Newton.' [ 1702 cf. FHP]
Newton dies, leaving his library with his niece, who leaves it to Earl of Portsmouth.
